chapter.title: 33 Mycobacterium: Clinical and Laboratory Characteristics of Rapidly Growing Mycobacteria

sect1.title: 33 Mycobacterium: Clinical and Laboratory Characteristics of Rapidly Growing Mycobacteria

para.phrase: BARBARA A. BROWN-ELLIOTT, SUSAN M. HARRINGTON, KOZO MORIMOTO, AND RICHARD J. WALLACE, JR.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY AND DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENTS
sect2.para: The rapidly growing mycobacteria (RGM) are generally defined as nontuberculous species that grow mature colonies on laboratory media within 7 days (1–3). RGM contain long-chain fatty acids, known as mycolic acids, that can be quantitated with chromatographic techniques such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). Prior to the molecular era, HPLC was used for identification of RGM species in most major reference laboratories. However, this method has been replaced in most laboratories by more definitive molecular and/or proteomic (matrix-assisted desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry, or MALDI-TOF MS) identification methods for more accurate species identification (4–6).

Currently, there are almost 200 species of nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), among which almost 100 species are RGM. More than half of the RGM species have been described since the early 1990s (7). A 2018 publication by Gupta et al. proposed a major revision of the NTM taxonomy based on phylogenetic and comparative genomic assays. The species of the M. abscessus/chelonae group were reclassified as Mycobacteriodes, whereas the remainder of the RGM were reclassified as Mycolicibacterium (8). Although the Gupta et al. taxonomic studies are scientifically accurate, in the sense that several clades exist within the mycobacteria, many mycobacteriologists have agreed that the confusion caused by changing the well-known genus Mycobacterium would be a costly and potentially dangerous and destructive decision. Consequently, many mycobacteriologists, especially in the clinical arena, have elected to retain the genus Mycobacterium, which is still considered valid by the Bacteriological Code of taxonomy (9, 10).

A subsequent investigation published in 2021 used a multifaceted approach for the taxonomic definition of a genus, including the evaluation of 16S rRNA gene similarity, amino acid identity index, average nucleotide identity, alignment fraction, and percentage of conserved proteins, which strongly disputed the proposed division of the mycobacterial genus into five genera. Thus, the investigators advised a reapplication of all species within the genusMycobacterium with the previously proposed five genera potentially as subgenus complex names (11).

Since 2017, 16 new validated species,M. aquiterrae (12), M. aquaticum (13), M. eburneum (14), M. grossiae (15), M. komaniense (16), M. kyogaense (17), M. lehmannii (18), M. malmesburyense (19), M. neglectum (20), M. neumannii (18), M. palauense (20), M. stellerae (21), M. baixiangningiae (22), M. mengxianglii (22), M. stephanolepidis (23), and M. syngnathidarum (24), have been added to the list. The last two species are fish pathogens but currently are not recovered from human clinical samples. M. malmesburyense and M. komaniense have been recovered from bovine nasal swabs, soil, and water in South Africa. Of major importance clinically is the cross-reactive immune response with M. bovis antigens, which could lead to a false diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis (16, 19).

Of these new species, only two,M. grossiae and M. eburneum, have been recovered from human clinical sources: M. grossiae from human respiratory and blood specimens and M. eburneum from a sputum sample. However, no clinical details were given concerning the patient from whom the M. eburneum isolate was recovered (14). Recently, M. eburneum described in 2017 has been merged with a slowly growing mycobacterial species, M. talmoniae. Although first described as an RGM, the growth rate was 7 days for M. eburneum compared to a 7- to 10-day average growth rate for M. talmoniae. Both species contain the 16S rRNA slowly growing mycobacteria genetic signature and are considered to be the same species (25).

There are currently six major groups or complexes of RGM, based on pigmentation and genetic relatedness (Table 1). The first group of nonpigmented pathogenic species includes 11 taxa, some of which once belonged to the third biovariant of the M. fortuitum group (Table 1) (1, 26–29).

The second group of nonpigmented RGM is theM. chelonae/M. abscessus complex listed in Table 1 (1, 30–33). Importantly, the M. abscessus species has been subdivided into three subspecies collectively (sensu lato) referred to as “M. abscessus species.” The former species M. abscessus is now designated M. abscessus subsp. abscessus. Two previously described species, M. massiliense and M. bolletii, which had been combined and proposed to form another subspecies of M. abscessus designated as M. abscessus subsp. bolletii, were reexamined and found by genomic sequence data to represent two separate subspecies (34, 35). The previously combined designation (i.e., M. abscessus subsp. bolletii) was controversial since no functional erm gene is present in isolates previously named M. massiliense, in contrast to the case for isolates previously called M. bolletii, with a functional erm gene conferring inducible macrolide resistance. Thus, the 2012 descriptions of the genomic sequences of M. abscessus subsp. bolletii (previously M. bolletii) and M. abscessus subsp. massiliense (previously M. massiliense) helped to resolve questions surrounding the species and provided information to better discriminate between the subspecies (36–38).

A 2017 phylogenetic study of NTM species by Tortoli and colleagues revealed, by genome-to-genome comparisions, thatM. farcinogenes, M. conceptionense, and M. senegalense were all very closely related and that their pairwise ANI values (98.3 to 99.4) suggested that these three currently recognized species may be variants of the same species (39). Thus, although M. farcinogenes is phenotypically a slowly growing NTM, current molecular identification schema place it within the M. fortuitum group (25). Later genomic evidence lists these three species as synomyms of each other (25). Additionally, a new member of the group similar to M. chelonae, M. stephanolepidis, is a fish pathogen (23).

Two subspecies ofM. chelonae have also been recently recognized, M. chelonae subsp. bovis (validly published, but an illegitimate name in need of replacement) (https://lpsn.dsmz.de/subspecies/mycobacterium-chelonae-bovis) and M. chelonae subsp. gwakanae (40, 41). Both subspecies have been isolated in Korea. M. chelonae subsp. bovis has been isolated from Korean native bovine species (Hanwoo, Bos taurus coreanas) (41), while M. chelonae subsp. gwakanae has been isolated from sputum samples in Korean patients with pulmonary disease coinfected with M. yongonense (41).
A third nonpigmented group, theM. mucogenicum group, currently includes three species, as noted in Table 1 (1, 31, 42).
The fourth group, theM. smegmatis group, is currently composed of the two late-pigmented species, i.e., M. smegmatis and M. goodii (1, 27, 43).

The fifth group of RGM includes the early-pigmented species, which traditionally have been difficult to identify by conventional (phenotypic) laboratory methods. Proven pathogens in this group includeM. neoaurum and M. bacteremicum (Table 1), which have been associated with mycobacteremia in patients with catheter infections, and M. iranicum, which has been recovered from five respiratory samples, a hand wound, and two cerebrospinal fluid samples (44–46). Several newly described early-pigmented species, including M. canariasense, M. cosmeticum, M. monacense, and M. grossiae, appear to be clinically significant (5, 46). M. cosmeticum has been described from granulomatous lesions associated with mesotherapy clinics and nail salons. There are several previously listed environmental (nonpathogenic) species as well as species described since 2017 including M. aquiterrae, M. lehmanii, M. neumanii, M. komaniense, M. baixiangningiae, M. mengxianglii, and M. stellerae (12, 16, 18, 21, 22). Current studies based on DNA sequence analysis have identified the presence of a sixth, nonpigmented pathogenic group composed of M. mageritense and M. wolinskyi (6, 32).

The introduction of the new species noted above within the RGM emphasizes the importance of molecular identification to the species level and questions the meaningfulness of the current “group” classifications, especially for theM. fortuitum group. However, because previous data (prior to the reliance on genetic testing) and publications use this “group” nomenclature, these designations are retained in this chapter for ease of discussion (1). As more information is obtained using advanced molecular technology and more laboratories adopt newer methodologies, the group designations may become even more obsolete.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: The RGM are opportunistic pathogens that cause disease in a variety of clinical settings. The three major clinically important species of RGM, responsible for approximately 80% of mycobacterial disease in humans, are theM. fortuitum group (including M. fortuitum, M. porcinum, M. senegalense, and other less commonly encountered species) (see Table 2), the M. chelonae complex, and the M. abscessus species, including M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, and M. abscessus subsp. bolletii (29, 47, 48). Other potentially pathogenic and clinically significant RGM species are also provided in Table 3 (1, 5, 6, 26, 27, 31–33, 43, 46, 49, 50). Infections caused by the M. abscessus species are often more challenging to treat than those due to other species because of multidrug resistance as well as delayed diagnosis. When a bacterial infection is suspected, but the routine culture test is negative, culture for mycobacteria should be initiated to result in timely diagnosis. Because of the relatively rapid growth of RGM, they may on occasion be detected from samples processed for bacterial culture prior to being finalized, often appearing in 2 to 3 days, unlike for slowly growing mycobacterial species.

sect1.title: Skin and Soft Tissue Infections
sect1.para: The major mechanism for acquiring NTM-associated skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) is direct contact with contaminated material or water through traumatic injury, procedure-related wounds, or environmental exposure. Secondary involvement of SSTIs during disseminated disease may also occur (51). Although these patients are generally healthy, drug-induced immune suppression leads to increased risk for this type of infection. In addition, SSTIs are associated with important stigma, deformity, and disability. The clinical picture of traumatic and procedure-related wound infection ranges from localized cellulitis, nonhealing ulcers, chronic nodular lesions, and abscesses to progressive tenosynovitis. Osteomyelitis can also ensue depending on the severity and wound type, such as with open fracture (52). (See following section on “Bone and Joint Infections.”) The majority of infections occur 4 to 6 weeks following wounds or procedures and generally exhibit local redness and swelling with spontaneous drainage. Sinus tract formations and intermittent drainage are commonly observed (53). Metal puncture wounds (48%) and injuries from motor vehicle accidents (26%) are the most common antecedent injuries, and approximately 40% of injury sites involve the foot or leg (54).

Although any of the more than 30 pathogenic RGM species listed inTable 2 can cause disease, M. fortuitum is the most common SSTI species among RGM, and patients infected with the M. fortuitum group (including the species noted in Table 2) have usually undergone a surgical procedure or experienced penetrating trauma, such as open fracture at the infected site. In contrast, patients infected with M. chelonae or the M. abscessus species tend to be older and are more likely to have an underlying health condition, and usually have multiple (disseminated) cutaneous lesions, as opposed to those with single (localized) lesions due to M. fortuitum (55). (See section on “Disseminated Cutaneous Disease.”) M. chelonae may be responsible for sporadic cases of localized wound infections following trauma or medical or surgical procedures, including needle injections.

sect2.title: Outbreaks Related to Footbaths (Nail Salons) and Tattooing
sect2.para: Starting in 2000, an outbreak of furunculosis (infection of hair follicles) on the lower extremities caused byM. fortuitum was described for 32 otherwise healthy patients who were patrons of a nail salon in California (footbaths precede pedicures at nail salons) (56). The organism was also cultured from contaminated footbaths and from inlet suction screens containing hair and other debris, and the recovered isolates were indistinguishable by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE). Leg shaving prior to the footbath and pedicure was identified as a significant risk factor (56). The follow-up report revealed that most of the cases could be treated with oral antibiotics without surgical intervention, and more than two antibiotics tailored to the organism were recommended. Other species, including the M. abscessus species and M. mageritense, were subsequently recovered from cases in California, North Carolina, and Georgia (1, 57, 58).

In late 2011 and early 2012, an outbreak of 19 cases ofM. chelonae associated with tattoo ink was reported in New York (59). This was the largest documented outbreak of this type involving M. chelonae. Reported skin lesions were mainly restricted to the gray ink color, suggesting that infection might have occurred through a specific premixed tattoo ink. A total of 114 reported cases were analyzed in a systematic review (60); M. chelonae was the most common, with other RGM species, such as M. immunogenum, the M. abscessus species, and M. fortuitum, also reported. Because tattooing has become very popular, the incidence rate and number of reported cases may have been underestimated. Fractionated CO2 laser cosmetic resurfacing has also been associated with RGM infections (61). However, in a report from North Carolina, isolates, the M. abscessus species isolates and M. chelonae isolates did not match those obtained from the clinic, suggesting that the infection was acquired post procedure.

sect1.title: Bone and Joint Infections
sect1.para: RGM may also cause bone and joint infections. Similar to bacterial disease, osteomyelitis may occur after open bone fractures and puncture wounds. The most common scenario is an open fracture of the femur, often followed by orthopedic surgical procedures. This type of infection may be due to disseminated-type disease. Moreover, the causative species may vary depending on the clinical setting, but the pathogen most frequently recovered in this setting is theM. fortuitum group, including the rare species M. houstonense, M. boenickei, and M. setense (1, 26, 62). One species in the M. smegmatis group, M. goodii, and one species in the M. mageritense/wolinskyi group, M. wolinskyi, have also been associated with osteomyelitis (1, 43). Bone involvement secondary to a puncture wound is likely the second major cause of osteomyelitis, and such infections most commonly involve the M. fortuitum group (1). An increasing cause of bone and joint infections are prosthetic knee and joint infections caused by M. fortuitum and M. chelonae (62).

These bone and joint infections usually occur in immunocompetent patients who have an apparent predisposing trauma or penetrating injury or who have undergone surgical procedures. Nevertheless, vertebral osteomyelitis (VO) is unusual in such patients; indeed, approximately half of VO cases develop in immunocompromised patients, and 85% of cases do not have any direct inoculation events (63). In these cases, blood-borne infection is suspected, especially in immunosuppressed patients. An outbreak of septic arthritis due to M. abscessus. subsp. massiliense among patients who had intra-articular injections of a steroid mixed with an analgesic at a single clinic was reported in South Korea (64).

sect1.title: Pulmonary Infections
sect1.para: Chronic lung infections with RGM, most often in nonsmoking older women with bronchiectasis, are sometimes associated with theM. avium complex (MAC). The M. abscessus species is the causative agent in approximately 80% of cases of pulmonary disease due to RGM, but geographical variations have been noted (47). M. abscessus is also the most intractable NTM species; radiological findings are the same as for MAC disease, with a fibrocavitary type and nodular-bronchiectatic type disease (65). The proportion of the three subspecies (M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, or M. abscessus subsp. bolletii) is dependent on the country or region (66–69). At present, there is no explanation for the apparently variable geographic distribution of M. abscessus subsp. massiliense strains in the population with respiratory disease. Data show a relatively higher proportion (44 to 56%) in Asian countries than in the United States (28%), and European countries, such as the Netherlands (21%) (66, 67, 69). The proportion and geographical distribution of a point mutation at position 28 (T28C), which results in inactivation of erm(41) in M. abscessus subsp. abscessus and consequential retention of susceptibility to macrolides, are unknown. M. abscessus subsp. bolletii is rarely associated with disease in any of the geographical areas.

Typically, MAC is the most commonly identified NTM in pulmonary disease, and approximately 20 to 30% of theM. abscessus species cases have previous MAC disease (70, 71). Therefore, subsequent positive culture for the M. abscessus species among MAC pulmonary diseases is not uncommon. Conversely, some patients from whom the M. abscessus species are first cultured also have secondary positive cultures for MAC. There are similarities between patients infected with MAC and with the M. abscessus species, and a common pathogenicity or host susceptibility factor may be involved. Less than 20% of M. abscessus subsp. abscessus and M. abscessus subsp. massiliense infections are associated with fibrocavitary-type disease, and there is no difference in the time to progression between the two groups (69). Because of a nonfunctional erm gene, patients with M. abscessus subsp. massiliense are successfully treated with macrolides more often than patients infected with M. abscessus subsp. abscessus (72 to 80% success rate, in contrast to 25 to 35% for patients with M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, usually with a functional erm gene) (67–69).

sect2.title: Cystic Fibrosis
sect2.para: Over the past 2 decades, the discovery of drugs that modulate the synthesis and function of the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein has resulted in the oldest and healthiest CF population in history (72). Thus, there is the possibility that improved CF treatment might contribute to the apparent increase in NTM prevalence among patients. Patients with CF also have bronchiectasis, in addition to chronic, recurrent airway and pulmonary parenchymal infections, which may be primary risk factors for susceptibility to NTM disease (73). Furthermore, NTM pulmonary disease is associated with a rapid decline in forced expiratory volume in the first second of expiration (FEV1) in CF patients (74). In CF patients with a macrolide-resistant M. abscessus species infection, lung transplant decisions are challenging, and the transplant may not be performed (72, 75).

TheM. abscessus species are the second most common group of NTM recovered from CF patients (after MAC, but some centers report a greater frequency), and it may be the most common species associated with clinical disease in this setting (73). A 2012 study concluded that CF patients with the M. abscessus species were younger and had more severe disease and more frequent intravenous antimicrobial treatment than those with MAC infection (76). The first possible human-to-human transmission of NTM was reported in 2012 in Seattle in CF patients with M. abscessus subsp. massiliense (77). This finding was further investigated, and isolates that genetically matched the strain with possible human-to-human transmission have been detected in several geographic areas outside the United States, including the United Kingdom and South America, which provides preliminary corroborative evidence for the unusual type of transmission (36, 77–79). In addition, more than 1,000 M. abscessus species clinical isolates have been obtained from 517 CF patients in Europe, the United States, and Australia. The study reported the isolation of nearly identical clones from various geographically distant locations. Approximately 74% of CF patients worldwide are infected with two M. abscessus subsp. abscessus clusters or one M. abscessus subsp. massiliense cluster (80). Although these findings suggest the possibility of global spread among CF patients, there are scant reports from areas with few CF patients.

sect2.title: Chronic Aspiration Syndrome and Miscellaneous Lung Disease
sect2.para: TheM. fortuitum group has been reported as a pathogen in half of cases of chronic aspiration disease secondary to underlying gastroesophageal disorders, such as achalasia (1, 47). However, M. fortuitum pulmonary disease is rare and often does not require treatment, though cases of extensive disease associated with lipoid pneumonia, as has also been seen in a few cases due to M. chelonae and M. smegmatis, have been reported (81, 82). A rare case of pulmonary disease with M. mageritense was described for a patient with a compromised immune system (1, 83). Nevertheless, the outbreak of M. porcinum discussed below described the first reported cases of clinically significant pulmonary disease associated with this species, a member of the M. fortuitum group (48).

sect2.title: Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis
sect2.para: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis among metal grinders working with contaminated metal-working fluids (MWF) in industrial plants has been associated withM. immunogenum (1, 47). Multiple pseudo-outbreaks associated with this species resulting from contaminated automated bronchoscope cleaning machines and MWF have been reported. This species can grow and remain viable in degraded MWF, and it is resistant to the routine biocides used for disinfection of MWF. Exposure to the contaminated MWF results in an allergic hypersensitivity pneumonitis (1, 47). To date, this species has not been detected in open lung biopsy specimens from these patients.

sect1.title: Central Nervous System Disease
sect1.para: Although central nervous system disease involving RGM is rare, morbidity and mortality are high.M. fortuitum is the most common species, followed by the M. abscessus species and M. mucogenicum (1, 84). Meningitis is the typical clinical presentation, manifesting as headache, fever, and neck stiffness. CSF findings usually show low glucose, high protein, and elevated white blood cells (84). Acquisition modes include otolaryngological disease, previous neurosurgery, and CNS catheters (i.e., ventriculoperitoneal shunt or epidural catheters). Therefore, if a patient with antecedent trauma or surgery or an immunosuppressed state has a chronic presentation and neutrophilic CSF, RGM infection should be suspected. In general, infections due to the M. abscessus species and M. mucogenicum have high mortality. Early clinical suspicion is critical, with an impact on management and outcome (85). A patient infected with M. abscessus subsp. massiliense who survived was reported in a small case series. Treatment with steroids is recommended in those with substantial meningeal involvement (84).

sect1.title: Ocular Infections
sect1.para: The spectrum of ocular infections caused by NTM includes keratitis, canaliculitis, scleral buckle infections, conjunctivitis, scleritis, and endophthalmitis (86), and the number of RGM ocular infections has been increasing. In a large study that analyzed 100 ophthalmic cases, the majority of patients were infected with RGM (95%), and the causative species were M. chelonae (44%), the M. abscessus species (38%), and the M. fortuitum group (9%) (87). With advances in refractive surgery, other descriptions of epidemic and sporadic ocular infections, especially infections following laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) surgery (1, 87), have increased dramatically since the early 1990s. Endophthalmitis is a severe intraocular infection. Approximately 88% of cases of endophthalmitis occur exogenously due to RGM, and cataract surgery is the most common procedure related to infection (88). If patients have a history of previous trauma, previous surgery, or compromised immunity, the possibility of NTM infection should be suspected, especially when refractory to topical antibiotics (89). Steroids should be avoided for keratitis treatment. A study that analyzed species involved in ocular infection in Taiwan found that 11 of 24 isolates were M. abscessus subsp. massiliense.

sect1.title: Otitis Media
sect1.para: The most common NTM ear diseases are chronic otitis media and otomastoiditis caused byM. abscessus species. Ear diseases caused by NTM are common in children, but adult cases are often reported in Asian countries. The entry route of NTM into the middle ear is speculated to involve two distinct routes: a tympanostomy tube with spread to the middle ear through the eustachian tube, and spread via the use of contaminated surgical instruments (90). In an outbreak of 17 cases of otitis media in two ear-nose-throat clinics, patients presented with chronic ear drainage with a perforated tympanic membrane and a prior tympanostomy tube (1). This is the characteristic scenario of such cases, and mycobacterial infections should be suspected. Sporadic cases of this disease continue to be reported. The key to the disease appears to be the presence of a foreign body (tympanostomy tube) and multidrug resistance. Treatment for the macrolide-resistant M. abscessus species consists of long-term parenteral or intravenous antibiotic combination therapy along with surgical intervention (90). Otitis media and otomastoiditis caused by M. abscessus subsp. massiliense (macrolide susceptible) were described for middle-aged adults with underlying otologic disease. These patients were treated successfully with clarithromycin-containing regimens for up to 9 months (91).

sect1.title: Health Care-Associated Infections
sect1.para: Health care-associated disease with RGM has been reported most commonly forM. fortuitum, M. chelonae, the M. abscessus species, and M. mucogenicum, though any species may be involved. Most infections occur following contamination with tap water (1, 92, 93). Types of infections include postsurgical wound infections, catheter sepsis, infections following hemodialysis, postinjection abscesses, and otitis media following tympanostomy tube replacement (1, 93). Both sporadic cases and localized outbreaks have occurred. Cosmetic procedure-associated infections caused by liposuction, liposculpture, acupuncture, and mesotherapy have also occurred (93–96). Because some cosmetic procedures include surgical intervention and are performed at a health care facility, the differences between health care- and cosmetic procedure-associated infections are sometimes obscure and can be included in this category (97, 98).

Two recent outbreaks involvingM. abscessus infections following pulpotomy in pediatric dental clinics have been published (97, 98), including a report of 24 school-aged children in Atlanta, Georgia, with inducibly macrolide-resistant M. abscessus species. Twelve children received antibiotics, one child underwent lymph node resection, and 11 children needed postsurgical antibiotics following incomplete surgical excision or presence of pulmonary nodules. Five children experienced serious adverse events during treatment including nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, neutropenia, and rash. An epidemiological investigation suggested the outbreak was associated with the use of tap water during pulpotomy. After a change to treated distilled water, no other cases have been reported (97).

The second and largest odontogenic outbreak to date identified 71 pediatric patients (22 confirmed and 49 probable) in Orange County, California. All case patients required surgical procedures and 26 of 70 hospitalized patients required more than one surgery. Tissue samples from 19 of 22 patients grewM. abscessus; 1 of 22 was identified as M. chelonae, and 2 of 22 were acid-fast bacteria unable to be identified from culture. Similar to the Georgia cases, adverse events were common and the outbreak was associated with the use of nonsterile water. Following the outbreak, a new California law was passed which specified the use of nonsterile water or water without appropriate antibacterial properties as “unprofessional conduct.” All patients recovered despite extensive jaw debridements and pulmonary involvement (98).

More than 2,000 cases of surgical-site infections after video-laparoscopic and arthroscopic surgical procedures caused by RGM were reported by the Brazilian national agency from 2003 to 2008 (99), and analyses of more than 150 strains from different states revealed that they belong to a single M. abscessus subsp. massiliense strain (BRA100) (100, 101). Additionally, it was noteworthy that the strain was resistant to 2% glutaraldehyde disinfectants used for disinfecting surgical equipment between surgeries (99, 102). Reports of surgically related infections decreased after 2008 after control measures were implemented by the Brazilian authority, but additional infections were reported in a different area of Brazil in 2010 (103). Interestingly, some studies have indicated a molecular relationship between the BRA100 clone and strains from Taiwan, Malaysia, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

Outbreaks of NTM wound infections, especially with theM. abscessus species, have occurred among “lipotourists” from the United States who travel abroad to undergo cosmetic surgery. From 2003 to 2004, 20 U.S. tourists who underwent abdominoplasty in the Dominican Republic developed M. abscessus species postsurgical infections (94); 8 who underwent surgery in the same clinic were infected with identical isolates. The remaining patients who carried different strains of the M. abscessus species underwent surgery in different clinics but otherwise had clinical presentations and demographic characteristics similar to those of the other patients (94).

Biomesotherapy, a therapy used (mostly outside of the U.S.) for pain management and general well-being, which includes injection of unregulated supplements and homeopathic formulations, has also been associated with outbreaks ofM. chelonae and the M. abscessus species (104, 105). In addition to true outbreaks, numerous health care-associated pseudo-outbreaks have been described. Contaminated or malfunctioning equipment, including bronchoscopes and automated endoscope cleaning machines, as well as contaminated laboratory reagents and ice, have been implicated (1, 93, 104).

A 2013–2014 outbreak ofM. abscessus species at a tertiary care hospital in the southeastern United States involved infections in lung transplant patients following surgery. Multiple interventions in patient care, including institution of sterile water for consumption, oral care, and bathing, and water engineering were implemented, and the outbreak subsided. Molecular strain typing by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and multilocus sequence typing identified two clonal strains of the M. abscessus species among clinical isolates, one of which was isolated from the hospital water supply in a new medical tower (106).

A 2014 cluster of six surgical site infections following cardiothoracic surgery due toM. wolinskyi were reported from a single academic medical center. No single point source of infection or environmental source was identified, but a self-contained heater/cooler unit used in cardiothoracic surgeries and a cold-air blaster were suspected as potential sources of infection. Removal of the units resulted in an end of the outbreak (107). A similar outbreak in France was also investigated with implementation of special infection control mediations (108). Although outbreaks related to cosmetic procedure-associated infections have been mainly reported in South American countries, any country may be involved and have inherent risks.

sect2.title: Catheter-Related Infections
sect2.para: Central catheter-associated infections are the most common health care-associated infections due to RGM (1, 48, 51, 78). Indeed, they are the most common cause of RGM bacteremia, but the disease may also present as local wound drainage as part of an exit site or tunnel infection (1, 51, 78, 81). Thus, symptoms range from local manifestations of catheter infection sites to systemic inflammatory responses. M. mucogenicum, M. fortuitum, the M. abscessus species, and the pigmented species M. bacteremicum (44) are the most common pathogens in central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). Notably, M. mucogenicum is indistinguishable from M. phocaicum by 16S rRNA sequencing analysis because the sequences are completely identical. Rare RGM, such as M. neoaurum, M. canariasense, and M. phocaicum, have also been reported to cause catheter-related infections. An outbreak of M. phocaicum and M. mucogenicum was described for five patients with central venous catheters in an oncology unit in a Texas hospital (93).

Peritoneal catheter infection can involve the catheter insertion site, the tunnelling tract, and the peritoneum. Peritonitis leads to a high rate of catheter withdrawal and relatively high mortality. Because a low percentage of patients stop peritoneal dialysis when a catheter is removed before developing peritonitis, it is recommended that the catheter be removed when exit site infection occurs. Other types of infection due to ventriculoperitoneal shunts and shunts for hemodialysis have also been reported.

sect2.title: Prosthetic Devices
sect2.para: Prosthetic device infections, including prosthetic heart valves, artificial knees and hips, lens implants, and metal rods inserted into the vertebrae to stabilize bones following fractures, have been described (62). Again, M. fortuitum is the most common pathogen, but any pathogenic RGM, including the M. smegmatis group, can be associated with this type of infection (62).

sect2.title: Transplant Patients
sect2.para: In transplant patients, infections caused by RGM are more of a problem in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) than in solid-organ transplantation and are often caused byM. fortuitum, the M. abscessus species, M. chelonae, M. mucogenicum, and rarely M. neoaurum (109). The risk of NTM infection in HSCT patients is 50 to 600 times higher than that in the general population (109), with a wide range of onset times from 1 to 35 months after transplantation (110). The most common manifestation of RGM infection in HSCT patients is central venous catheter infection. In solid-organ transplant patients, skin and soft-tissue infections are commonly associated with surgical sites and long-term intravenous or peritoneal catheters (111).

sect2.title: Surgical Wound Infections
sect2.para: Surgical wound infections due to RGM are a well-recognized clinical entity. In the 1970s and 1980s, multiple outbreaks of disease occurred, and these were most commonly associated with augmentation mammoplasty and coronary artery bypass surgery (1, 93, 112). (See “Health Care-Associated Infections,” above.) Infections following these types of surgery are now less common, although a cluster of 12 cases of post-augmentation mammoplasty surgical site infections due to M. fortuitum and M. porcinum was reported between 2002 and 2004 in Brazil (112). More often, however, these infections now occur following other types of cosmetic surgeries, such as liposuction, breast reconstruction following mastectomy, and other types of prosthetic surgeries, such as knee replacements.

In a 1989 report (18), approximately 80% of RGM wound isolates related to cardiac surgery were from seven southern coastal states, including Texas, Louisiana, Georgia, Maryland, Alabama, Florida, and South Carolina. A second report, published in the same year, showed that 92% of 37 identified cases of surgical wound infection following augmentation mammoplasty were also from patients in southern coastal states, with the majority located in Texas, Florida, and North Carolina, suggesting that the disease risk was highest in the southeastern United States (1).

Recovery ofM. abscessus subsp. abscessus and M. abscessus subsp. massiliense has been reported from outbreaks of infections associated with laparoscopic surgeries and cosmetic surgeries in Brazil, the Dominican Republic, and Korea (93, 94, 96). These and other recent reports suggest that, although few studies have identified these newer subspecies in invasive infections, they may have been misclassified in previous studies (113).

A 2015 study involved 19 patients who developed postsurgical wound infections following caesarean sections, hernioplasty, diagnostic laproscopy, laproscopic cholecystectomy, and reduction mammoplasty in India (114). Although the isolates were identified using only biochemical testing and growth rate, the organisms present in the cultures included those of the M. fortuitum and the M. abscessus/chelonae groups.

All of the patients, except two who were lost to follow-up and two who relapsed following repeated incision and drainage and exploratory surgery, recovered following draining of abscesses and resection of any nodules along with antibiotic treatment with amikacin and clarithromycin (114).

In 2016, Wu and colleagues reportedM. abscessus subsp. massiliense in four postpartum women following caesarean sections in Taiwan from 2009 to 2012 (115). All four patients recovered following regimens of macrolides, amikacin, imipenem/cilastin, and tigecycline without surgical intervention. These two studies along with earlier reports highlight the importance of combining surgical and combination antibiotic therapy for wound infections due to the RGM. As stated previously, many of the other surgical wound infections involved outbreak situations and are discussed in “Health Care-Associated Infections,” above.

sect1.title: Infections Associated with Anti-IFN-γ Autoantibodies
sect1.para: NTM infections involving neutralizing anti-IFN-γ autoantibodies, known as “adult-onset immunodeficiency,” were first described in 2004 (116, 117). The IFN-γ–IL-12 pathway plays an essential role in the host immune response to intracellular pathogens (118). Most of the patients were immunocompetent Asian adults who presented with disseminated infections along with lymph node swelling. A review found that the mean age of onset was 52 ± 13.7 years; 64 patients (58%) were female, who were younger than the males in the study (48.8 ± 11.5 versus 56.3 ± 15.2 years) (119). Less than half of the cases also had a history of other opportunistic infections (e.g., salmonellosis, cryptococcosis, penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis) because of blockage of the IFN-γ–IL-12 pathway. Reactive dermatitis, such as Sweet’s syndrome and erythema nodosum, is also commonly reported, especially in RGM cases. The most common organs involved are the lymph nodes (79%), followed by the bones/joints (34%), lungs (32%), blood (24%), skin (18%), and bone marrow (11%). RGM (the M. abscessus species, M. fortuitum, and M. chelonae) were frequently isolated from more than half of the cases, even though M. avium is common in AIDS patients with disseminated NTM infection. It remains unclear whether these patients are more susceptible to RGM or if the findings merely reflected the environment of the susceptible host. Lymph node lesions and reactive dermatitis are more common in patients with RGM infection. Indeterminate results of the QuantiFERON TB test suggest antibody positivity in the serum (119).

A rare type of disseminated infection due to RGM in immune-competent hosts presenting with lymphadenopathy was recently described in patients from Thailand (120). These patients were ultimately shown to have anti-IFN-γ auto antibodies (120).

sect1.title: Disseminated Cutaneous Disease
sect1.para: For unknown reasons, disseminated cutaneous disease is rare for all taxonomic groups other than theM. abscessus/M. chelonae group, even in immune-compromised patients, including those with AIDS (1, 47, 121).

In contrast, disseminated cutaneous disease due to bothM. abscessus species (less frequently seen) and M. chelonae is more common and serious. Disease typically presents as multiple, chronic, painful red nodules, usually involving the lower extremities, in chronically immunosuppressed patients receiving corticosteroids (organ transplant recipients, patients with rheumatoid arthritis, and/or other autoimmune disorders or immunosuppressive therapy) (55), and the disease has no apparent portal of entry. Also, as with M. chelonae, patients with disseminated cutaneous infection due to M. abscessus species rarely have detectable bacteremia and/or endocarditis but usually present with multiple, draining, painful cutaneous nodules, usually in the lower extremities (1, 47). These lesions then drain spontaneously, with the drainage usually being acid-fast bacillus smear positive. With disease due to M. chelonae, almost all patients are immunosuppressed, usually from low-dose corticosteroid therapy. Although the disease is presumably a consequence of hematogenous spread, bacteremia is rarely identified in this clinical setting. A portal of entry for the infection is rarely evident (1, 47). In a series of 100 clinical isolates from skin and soft tissue, 53% were from patients with disseminated cutaneous infections (1).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Details of standard methods are included inchapter 30 of this Manual. Transport of specimens is accomplished by using leakproof containers and proper safety protocols. Specimens for detection of RGM should be delivered to the laboratory in a timely manner, following appropriate shipping and handling regulations for shipping biological or infectious materials (122).

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: The use of mycobacterial smears is a rapid and reasonably sensitive step in the diagnosis of RGM disease. Gram stains showing faintly staining, “ghost-like” beaded Gram-positive bacilli are often helpful in establishing a diagnosis of mycobacteriosis. Ziehl-Neelsen or Kinyoun staining may also be useful. However, the use of smears alone is not sufficient for species identification. A large study found that NTM, including RGM, are likely to be detected by fluorochrome staining of specimens, especially those from patients at low risk for AIDS in areas where lung disease is endemic (122, 123). Further details of the staining procedures are found in chapter 30 of this Manual.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Currently, there are no commercial nucleic acid detection systems available for direct detection of NTM. An indirect method could be identifying an acid-fast bacillus smear-positive sample that is negative by a nucleic acid amplification test specific forM. tuberculosis, but this does not distinguish between RGM and the slowly growing NTM.

sect1.title: Laboratory-Developed Tests
sect1.para: PCR amplification and sequencing has been used to detect and identify NTM in specimens from sterile sites, but these tests are generally limited to larger, reference laboratories. Culture-independent methods for detection of NTM from specimens containing mixed microbiota are uncommon. A few small studies conducted among CF patients have focused on detection ofM. abscessus and MAC. Published methods have included a multiprobe real-time PCR assay using hsp65 with melt analysis to distinguish common mycobacterial species (124), quantitative PCR using an rpoB target (125), and PCR amplification of 16S rRNA followed by next-generation sequencing (126). The glycopeptidolipids and mycolic acids of the mycobacterial cell wall, complex CF sputum specimen matrices, and relatively low mycobacterial organism burden may make detection of M. abscessus in CF specimens more challenging than nonmycobacerial species. Analytical sensitivity might be enhanced by incorporating bead-beating with 0.1-mm zirconium beads in the extraction process (126). Unfortunately, sensitivity for detection of the M. abscessus species has generally not been better than smear (124, 126).

Whole-genome analysis and bioinformatics were used to identify molecular targets incorporated in a one-step multiplex PCR assay that has been described to detect five clinically significant NTM species, includingM. abscessus subsp. abscessus and M. abscessus subsp. massiliense (127). This assay is highly sensitive and specific for the M. abscessus species in culture, but is not yet evaluated from clinical specimens. A multiplex assay for the specific detection of the most common RGM was developed for use with the BD MAX platform (Becton Dickinson Diagnostic Systems, Sparks, MD), which automates extraction, PCR, and detection. The assay incorporates ITS sequences for detection of the M. abscessus species and M. chelonae, and rpoB for the M. fortuitum complex. It was evaluated with previously frozen clinical specimens from respiratory, wound, and other sources. Overall sensitivity compared to culture was 90% and specificity was 98% (128).

Metagenomic approaches for the detection of mycobacteria in clinical specimens are being developed, but are currently only available in research or large reference laboratories. Furthermore, results are usually reported on a research-use-only basis, as validation of such methods is complex. Barriers to implementation in clinical laboratories include dealing with the large proportion of human DNA sequences that may be present in comparison to bacterial DNA, the expense of the equipment, and the high level of computational skill required to analyze the sequencing datasets. Nevertheless, metagenomics has successfully been used to detectM. abscessus mixed with other pathogen(s) in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (129, 130). Future advancements in metagenomics are likely to make these methods more achievable for clinical laboratories.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Primary isolation of RGM optimally requires culture at 28 to 30°C rather than 35°C, especially for recovery ofM. chelonae and M. immunogenum (1). Direct examination and isolation procedures are detailed in chapter 30 of this Manual.
Recovery of RGM from routine blood culture systems does not appear to be problematic. However, no large comparative studies of commercial systems have been performed to date.

sect1.title: Biochemical Testing
sect1.para: As previously stated, the RGM are defined as NTM that grow mature colonies within 7 days (most species grow within 3 to 4 days) (1). Until the advent of more modern molecular techniques, traditional laboratory identification of the RGM was based primarily upon growth rate, pigmentation, colonial morphology, and a select battery of biochemical tests (1). These standard tests included tests of arylsulfatase production, tolerance to 5% NaCl, nitrate reductase activity, iron uptake, and carbohydrate utilization. All members of the M. fortuitum group and the M. chelonae/M. abscessus group exhibit a strongly positive arylsulfatase reaction at 3 days. The M. smegmatis group (M. smegmatis and M. goodii) and M. wolinskyi have similar growth rates but do not exhibit arylsulfatase activity at 3 days (1, 43). Approximately 95% of the isolates of M. smegmatis and 80% of M. goodii isolates develop a late (7 to 10 days) yellow-orange pigmentation (1, 43).

We recommend that biochemical testing of the RGM should be replaced by molecular genetic or proteomic methods (i.e., DNA sequencing or MALDI-TOF MS). Moreover, although biochemical testing is recommended by some journals when describing a new species as part of a polyphasic identification algorithm, strict quality control should be exercised, because these tests are not routinely performed.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests for Taxonomic Identification
sect1.para: Other adjunctive nonmolecular tests, including antimicrobial susceptibility tests, have been utilized for preliminary identification of the RGM (1, 131). They are less commonly used with the advent of molecular techniques, but they can help to provide species confirmation in conjunction with molecular genetic or proteomic results. As a screening tool, isolates of the M. fortuitum group and the M. chelonae/M. abscessus group can be differentiated by the use of a polymyxin B (300 IU) disk diffusion method. Generally, isolates of the M. fortuitum group exhibit a partial or clear zone of inhibition (≥10 mm) around the polymyxin disk, whereas isolates of the M. chelonae/M. abscessus group show no zone of inhibition (1).

Moreover,M. chelonae and the M. abscessus species also have different antimicrobial susceptibility patterns. One major difference between the two species is resistance to cefoxitin. Isolates of M. chelonae generally have cefoxitin MICs of ≥256 μg/ml, whereas the modal MIC for isolates of the M. abscessus species is 32 to 64 μg/ml (1). Furthermore, isolates of M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, but not M. chelonae or M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, have an inducible erm gene similar to the gene in M. fortuitum, which conveys macrolide resistance (132, 133).

Isolates of theM. abscessus species also have lower amikacin MICs and are resistant to tobramycin, whereas tobramycin is more active than amikacin with M. chelonae. Additionally, isolates of M. chelonae are more susceptible in vitro to some of the newer antibiotics, including linezolid and moxifloxacin, than are isolates of the M. abscessus species (134).

It should still be emphasized that although the aforementioned testing is helpful, molecular genetic or proteomic identification is necessary for definitive identification of all NTM, including RGM (131).

sect2.title: HPLC Identification
sect2.para: HPLC analysis of the mycobacterial cell wall mycolic acid content is still routinely used in some large reference or public health department laboratories to identify slowly growing isolates of NTM, but it has been problematic with RGM (1, 135). HPLC can be helpful for placing RGM isolates into groups or complexes, but it is not specific enough to identify most species with a high degree of accuracy, and data are missing on some of the newer species.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Probes
sect2.para: The INNO-LiPA multiplex probe assay (Fujirebio Diagnostics, Inc., Belgium) is based on the principle of reverse hybridization (136). Although the assay has not received U.S. FDA clearance, it can identify both rapidly and slowly growing mycobacterial species. Biotinylated DNA obtained by PCR amplification of the 16S-23S internal transcribed spacer (ITS) is hybridized with specific oligonucleotide probes immobilized as parallel lines on membrane strips. The main advantage of this system is that a large variety of species may be identified by a single assay, without the need to select an appropriate probe. One limitation of the assay is that it fails to differentiate isolates of closely related species, such as M. chelonae and the M. abscessus species (136). Identification of the M. fortuitum group should be interpreted with caution as cross-reactivity may be detected with species of the M. fortuitum group and several species, such as M. thermoresistibile, M. agri, and M. alvei, that are rarely found in clinical samples (1, 136). Additionally, rare isolates of M. smegmatis have been reported that react with the M. fortuitum probe and not with the M. smegmatis probe (136, 137).

A similar commercial PCR method that targets the 23S rRNA gene, the GenoTypeMycobacterium assay (Hain Lifescience GmbH, Nehren, Germany), provides probes in two kits. The CM (“Common Mycobacteria”) kit identifies common RGM such as M. chelonae, M. abscessus complex, and the M. fortuitum group. Several less common species are identified with the AS (“Additional Species”) kit (138, 139). In addition, the recently developed GenoType NTM-DR kit contains probes that distinguish subspecies within the M. abscessus group and includes targets for characterization of aminoglycoside and macrolide resistance (140, 141). The INNO-LiPA and GenoType line probe systems are widely used in Europe for NTM identification.

sect1.title: Sequence Analysis
sect1.para: Nucleic acid sequence analysis has been performed for the identification of mycobacteria for several years. This identification tool has been useful for the discrimination of most of the newly described species of RGM (118, 142, 143).

Sequencing remains a complex and often cost-prohibitive expense for some routine clinical laboratories, which also may not have an adequate volume of isolates to warrant sequencing. Therefore, the consensus is that not all laboratories should attempt to incorporate sequencing into their laboratory routine. Moreover, requests for sequencing should instead be sent to a qualified reference laboratory with skill and experience in the method (143, 144).

sect1.title: Partial 16S rRNA Gene Sequence Analysis
sect1.para: Generally, the identification of mycobacteria, including RGM, focuses on two main hypervariable domains, known as region A and region B, located at the 5′ end of the 16S rRNA gene. These regions correspond toEscherichia coli positions 129 to 267 and 430 to 500, respectively. Hypervariable region A, especially, contains most of the species-specific sequence variations (so-called “signature sequences”) in mycobacterial species, and sequencing of this region allows taxonomic identification of most mycobacteria, including many species of RGM (6, 118).

Although not yet FDA cleared, a commercial gene sequencing system, the MicroSeq 500 16S rDNA bacterial sequencing kit (ThermoFisher, Carlsbad, CA), analyzes the first 500-bp sequence and compares the sequence with those in a commercially prepared database. The use of this commercial system alone cannot differentiate some major species of RGM, such asM. chelonae and the M. abscessus species, which require sequencing of other regions or other genes for identification (see Table 3) (131, 142, 143, 145). For this reason, clinical laboratories have supplemented the commercial database with additional sequences from their own in-house libraries or GenBank (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank).

The currently commercially available partial 16S rRNA gene sequencing system (MicroSeq first 500 bp) has a number of large gaps for identification of RGM. For example, isolates of two major RGM pathogens,M. chelonae and the M. abscessus species, require sequencing of sites outside the first 500 bp, as they are identical in this region but differ at other 16S rRNA gene sites (in the 3′ region) (118, 142) (see Table 4). To ensure accurate identification, at least 300 bp of quality sequence should be compared between the reference and query sequences and should cover at least one region of the gene where variations are to be expected. Therefore, most clinical laboratories currently sequence between 450 and 480 bp in order to provide an adequate sequence (118, 144).

In general, members of the genusMycobacterium are closely related to each other, and closely related species may differ by only a few base pairs, or none at all. For example, M. goodii, which is difficult to distinguish from M. smegmatis phenotypically except by susceptibility pattern, has only a four-base difference in the entire 16S rRNA gene (43).

A quality-controlled database is indispensable for the evaluation and accurate identification of unknown strains (143). The laboratorian should also recognize that sequence analysis is an important component in a polyphasic approach to the identification of unknown strains. While in some instances, molecular analysis-based identifications without conventional testing may be adequate, more often there are cases in which the broader picture must be reviewed. This includes exclusion of mixed cultures, and key phenotypic tests, including colonial morphology, pigmentation, and growth rate, are necessary, especially for the differentiation of closely related species (131, 143).
