sect1.para: The lack of consensus on standard reporting criteria or a cutoff value has been a major obstacle in interpretation of sequence data (143, 144). Reporting criteria, such as (i) distinct species, (ii) “related” to a species, and (iii) “most closely related to” a species, depending upon the amount of sequence difference between the unknown isolate and the 16S rRNA gene database entries (145), have been recommended but not validated (118, 143). Although 100% identity is mandatory for signature sequences, one or a few mismatches at other positions may be acceptable for identification to the species level (144).

sect1.title: Sequencing of the hsp65 Gene
sect1.para: Although the 65-kDa heat shock protein gene (hsp65) is highly conserved among species of mycobacteria, it exhibits more interspecies and intraspecies polymorphisms than those in the 16S rRNA gene sequence (146, 147). This variability can be advantageous for the development of other strategies for the identification of genetically related species of RGM (146). Most sequencing or restriction fragment length polymorphism analyses have utilized a 441-bp sequence identified by Telenti et al. (147), often referred to as the Telenti fragment.

Studies based on DNA sequencing have demonstrated interspecies allelic diversity within the RGM. Detailed studies of several RGM species, includingM. peregrinum, M. porcinum, M. senegalense, M. chelonae, and the M. abscessus species, have shown 4 to 6 sequence variants (sequevars) per species that differ by 4 to 6 nucleotides within the 441-bp Telenti fragment (147, 148). PCR restriction fragment analysis of hsp65 was an early valuable molecular tool for the identification of RGM but has generally been replaced with the more widespread availability of gene sequencing.

Additionally, unlike 16S rRNA gene sequencing, thehsp65 sequencing method can differentiate isolates of the M. abscessus species from those of M. chelonae (they differ by almost 30 bp in the 441-bp hsp65 sequence, compared to only 4 bp in the entire 1,500-bp 16S rRNA gene sequence) (148). In contrast to sequencing with the 16S rRNA gene, sequencing with the hsp65 gene can discriminate even RGM species with a high degree of 16S rRNA gene similarity, such as M. fortuitum, M. septicum, M. peregrinum, M. houstonense, and M. senegalense.

As with other sequencing methods, a constraint ofhsp65 gene sequencing has been that few sequences of newer RGM species are available in databases, and detailed sequencing of older species (i.e., multiple strains) has not been done, such that only one sequence per species is generally available. Since whole-genome sequencing is now recommended for newly described species, sequences for hsp65, as well as other targets described below, are generally available for at least a limited number of strains. However, development of a comprehensive database and in-house validation continue to be essential (6, 143, 148).

sect1.title: rpoB Sequence Analysis
sect1.para: Initial studies usingrpoB (the gene encoding the β-subunit of RNA polymerase) sequencing for description of species were based upon partial rpoB gene sequence analysis, comprising only about 20% of the entire gene length. Other investigators have suggested that species identification of a variety of RGM species is possible using a 340- to 360-bp region, but extensive variation may require development of more species-specific probes (31, 32, 149, 150).

The utility ofrpoB was emphasized in a 2004 study by Adekambi and Drancourt that compared the phylogenetic relationships among 19 RGM species, including the major pathogens in this group, by comparing rpoB to several different sequence targets, including the 16S rRNA gene, hsp65, sodA, and recA. All 19 species showed good discrimination with rpoB (151, 152).

Not only has therpoB sequence been useful for the identification of established species, but it has also helped to enable the discrimination of species that cannot be differentiated by the 16S rRNA gene or the hsp65 sequence alone. Newly described species that are usually differentiated by rpoB sequencing include M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, M. phocaicum, and M. aubagnense (31–33). However, recent studies have shown that multilocus sequencing is necessary to definitively identify M. abscessus subsp. massiliense (30, 34, 153).

sect1.title: Sequence Analysis of Other Gene Targets
sect1.para: Other molecular targets for taxonomic identification, including the 32-kDa protein gene, the superoxide dismutase gene (sodA), the 16S-23S rRNA ITS, dnaJ, secA1, and recA, have been suggested for mycobacterial identification utilizing either PCR-restriction fragment length analysis (PRA) or direct sequencing (153, 154). However, preliminary data suggest that these gene sequences may be more variable than hsp65, and, to date, they have been utilized less commonly for the laboratory identification of the species of RGM (32, 153, 154).

Moreover, a major limitation of all sequence-based testing is the lack of sufficient databases (32, 131, 143). Additionally, a multigenic approach for taxonomic evaluation of species has been suggested widely by investigators and was proposed by an ad hoc committee for the reevaluation of the species definition in bacteriology (155). As whole-genome sequence data are increasingly available, sequence data from less common targets and more mycobacterial species, including those newly described, can be used to build databases and understand mycobacterial diversity.

The 2010 studies by Kim et al. usederm(41) gene sequences to differentiate M. abscessus subsp. massiliense from M. abscessus subsp. abscessus and M. abscessus subsp. bolletii (156). The results of species identification using erm(41) were concordant with those of multilocus sequence analysis including rpoB, hsp65, sodA, and the 16S-23S ITS (156). However, Blauwendraat et al. reported that sequencing of sodA provides little value in species differentiation (157). Table 5 shows the erm gene designations for some of the commonly encountered RGM pathogens.

sect1.title: Multilocus Sequence Analysis
sect1.para: A 2009 study by Macheras et al. has shown the inaccuracy of single-target sequencing for differentiation of species within theM. abscessus species (i.e., M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, the former species M. massiliense, and the former species M. bolletii) (38). The previous strategy, using only rpoB sequencing for identification of subspecies within the M. abscessus species, appears to be unacceptable due to the composite genetic structure, which suggests that genetic exchanges among members of the group led to legitimate recombination events among homologous housekeeping genes in a large number of isolates of the M. abscessus species studied thus far (38, 153, 158).

These studies also emphasize the need for multiple-gene sequencing in the definition of species (38). A 2011 study by Macheras et al. suggested the use of eight housekeeping gene sequences (4,071 bp), including argH, cya, glpK, gnd, murC, pgm, pta, and purH (159). Their work also brings into question the previous criteria for differentiation of species based on >3% rpoB sequence divergence between two RGM species (159). Furthermore, their work substantiates later studies asserting that M. massiliense and M. bolletii are not different species (34, 39).

Recently, whole-genome sequencing (WGS) has been utilized for MLST. One approach extended MLST analysis by combininghsp65, rpoB, erm (41), and genes for resistance detection with housekeeping genes, yielding results for identification, resistance detection, and discrimatory strain typing for the M. abscessus species (160). As the cost of sequencing decreases and data analysis is simplified, WGS schemes may be within reach for routine use by clinical laboratories.

sect1.title: Pyrosequencing
sect1.para: Pyrosequencing technology (Biotage, Uppsala, Sweden) is based on the detection of pyrophosphate during DNA synthesis. During sequencing, visible light is produced that is proportional to the number of incorporated nucleotides.

The method uses short (20- to 30-bp) sequences and is not as discriminating as traditional Sanger sequencing, but it is an attractive and less expensive alternative. Another advantage of the pyrosequencing technology is its commercial availability, although it has not yet been FDA cleared. As with other sequencing methods, the major limitation is the quality of the databases for interpretation and comparison of sequences (161). In a 2005 study of 50 RGM isolates (M. chelonae/M. abscessus and M. mucogenicum), using the hypervariable region of 16S rDNA, consensus sequences were obtained for 40 isolates compared to traditional sequencing results. Of 10 isolates of M. fortuitum, 3 had identical sequences that matched those of M. fortuitum/M. peregrinum, and the remaining 7 isolates matched M. fortuitum (162). Chikamatsu et al. evaluated a collection of 72 RGM type strains including 43 species of unproven pathogenicity using two sequencing primers within hypervariable region A. Thirty-four (47.2%) were identified to species, 30 (41.6%) were distinguished to the group or complex level, and 8 (11.1%) could not be identified, generally due to poor-quality sequence data (163). To date, this method has provided reliable and rapid identification of a variety of RGM species (162).

Investigators have proposed the use of a segment of therpoB gene in conjunction with pyrosequencing to determine the sequence of a 60-bp portion of the rpoB gene. The sequence, located at positions 1105 to 1219 (including primer sequences) in variable region II according to the numbering of Adekambi et al. (31), successfully identified 99/100 isolates of M. abscessus and M. chelonae (164).

sect1.title: Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization–Time of Flight Mass Spectrometry
sect1.para: MALDI-TOF MS is a reliable and rapid technological advance for the identification of NTM, including the RGM. MALDI-TOF MS produces unique spectral fingerprints based on extracted proteins. Moreover, MALDI-TOF MS provides a less expensive and less labor-intensive procedural alternative to gene sequencing for identification of the RGM (165). Recent studies report the use of MALDI-TOF MS in conjunction with enhanced libraries, and extraction procedures can differentiate the most clinically relevant species of RGM (4, 165, 166).

Currently, the major commercial MALDI-TOF MS systems are the Bruker Biotyper (Bruker Daltonics, Billerica, MA) and bioMérieux VITEK MS (bioMérieux, Durham, NC). These systems contain a spectral database and identification algorithms for the detection of conserved and microbe-specific protein spectra patterns in whole-cell mass spectra (166–168). The most time-consuming portion of this method is the inactivation and protein extraction step. Most of the compiled data are based upon extraction from colonies on solid media. Numerous protocols for preparation of proteins can be found in the earliest literature. Saleeb et al. optimized the extraction process with the addition of bead-beating to disrupt the mycobacterial cell wall. This step proved to be advantageous for achieving quality spectra for some mycobacteria, particularly strains of the M. abscessus species and M. fortuitum (169). The Bruker and bioMérieux commercial systems have refined the recommended extraction procedures for use with their systems, and both recommend a bead-beating step with either a vortex mixer or bead-beating apparatus (170–172). Importantly, the extraction protocol used may be method- and database-specific. Confidence score and identification rate have been reported to be negatively impacted when the extraction method differs from the one used to establish the database (165, 172). However, shortened extraction protocols using Adaptive Focused Acoustics (AFA; Covaris, Woburn, MA), sonication, and bead-based homogenization prior to analysis with the Bruker MicroFlex LT system have also provided results for RGM equivalent to or better than those with manufacturer-recommended procedures (173–175).

The most recent version of the bioMérieux database (v3.2 Knowledge Base) has been FDA approved forin vitro diagnostic use and contains 162 unique RGM isolates representing the 6 most common species or species groups. Nine additional species that are not clinically validated are included in the database. There are essentially no differences between the current IVD v3.2 and IVD v3.0 databases with respect to RGM; the SARAMIS v4.16 library (bioMérieux, Marcy l’Étoile, France) adds several RGM species that are unproven human pathogens (176). For the VITEK MS, a reliable species identification has been established at a confidence score of >90% (176). A recent multicentered study of the VITEK MS system using the 3.0 database showed that the system could correctly identify 98% of 202 RGM to the species or complex level (171).

The most recent version of the Bruker MBT mycobacterial library v7.0 is RUO. Reference spectra were added to the library to improve recognition of species diversity and natural variability within theMycobacterium genus. The database currently contains 182 mycobacterial species, with over 90 RGM represented. In addition to the species in database v6.0, the latest database adds four mycobacterial species, only one of which may rarely be a human RGM pathogen. A confidence score of ≥1.8 is recommended by the manufacturer for high-confidence species identification (177).

A few studies have compared the Bruker and bioMérieux systems, but various extraction methods, early versions of the databases, and different interpretations of confidence scores were used, leading to some ambiguity when compared to current practices (165, 172, 178). Recently, Brown-Elliott et al. conducted a multicentered comparison study using the manufacturer-recommended extraction methods and versions 3.0 and 5.0 of the bioMérieux and Bruker databases, respectively (4). The findings of this study were generally consistent with earlier evalutions. A confidence score of ≥1.8 was used for acceptable identification to the species level with the Bruker Biotyper. Others have found that lowering the acceptable score improves the rate of identification to species with little sacrifice in accuracy, and applying an acceptable score of ≥1.8 is common practice for users of this system (166, 172, 179). The Biotyper system identified 115/125 (92%) and the VITEK MS system identified 124/125 (99.2%) RGM to at least the group or complex level. Importantly, both systems can distinguish the M. abscessus species from M. chelonae and accurately identify the M. abscessus species. Neither system identifies M. abscessus subspecies with the software used for routine identification. The Biotyper could not distinguish M. mucogenicum from M. phocaicum, and the VITEK MS identified all M. phocaicum as M. mucogenicum. Thus, neither system can distinguish members of the M. mucogenicum group. The Bruker system was better able to identify to the species level within the M. fortuitum complex, identifying 20/20 M. fortuitum subsp. fortuitum, 1/1 M. neworleansense, 1/8 M. senegalense/conceptionense, and 9/10 M. porcinum. One M. porcinum was misidentified as M. abscessus. VITEK MS reported all 39 isolates within the M. fortuitum group correctly to the group level. Identification of M. fortuitum group organisms to species may be clinically significant, because some species lack a functional erm gene and will likely be susceptible to macrolide antibiotics. The Biotyper correctly identified only 8/15 M. chelonae and misidentified 6/15 M. chelonae as M. salmoniphilum. Similarity of spectra for M. chelonae and M. salmoniphilum or M. stephanolepidis (neither of which are recognized pathogens) is a limitation recognized in software v7.0 release notes. In previous studies using earlier versions of the Biotyper library, some M. chelonae have produced low scores, prompting laboratories to supplement libraries with regional strains to improve accuracy of identification (165, 169, 172). The VITEK MS successfully identified all M. chelonae. Both systems were able to identify M. immunogenum and M. mageritense, with VITEK MS misidentifying 1/9 isolates of M. immunogenum as M. abscessus (4).

A third system, the ASTA MicroIDSys Elite, manufactured by ASTA (Suwon-si, Korea, and recently in the U.S. also) has recently emerged in the international market. Using the ASTA MycoDB v2.0 database for analysis of spectra, 25/26 (96.2%) RGM type strains were identified to the species or complex (M. fortuitum/M. porcinum). One M. holsaticum was misidentified as M. fortuitum complex. MicroIDSys identified 45/51 (88.2%) organisms to the species/complex from primary culture MGIT liquid media (Becton Dickinson, Sparks, MD) with 2 misidentifications (180).

Identification of mycobacteria in clinical samples from liquid media plays an important role in achieving rapid results but may be challenging due to the low levels of mycobacterial biomass in the medium when MALDI-TOF MS is employed (181). Additionally, there has been concern that identification from liquid media is hindered by clinical specimen and media components. Several investigators have demonstrated successful identification of RGM to species or complex using seeded media studies (170, 179). To address concerns related to the medium and specimen, Miller et al. conducted reagent interference and simulated sputum studies. They demonstrated that supplemented liquid media, digestion and decontamination reagents, contaminating bacteria, and sputum should not generate interfering peaks in spectral analysis. Furthermore, 139/140 (99.3%) samples spiked with RGM were accurately identified with no misidentifications (182). Extending incubation 24 to 72 hours beyond the time at which an automated system first detects growth, extracting from up to 3 ml of liquid medium, pipetting from the biomass at the bottom of the culture tube, and addition of a 0.5% SDS wash step are approaches that may improve the rate of successful identification from clinical cultures (180, 183, 184).

Just as for genetic sequencing methods, the importance of an extensive database for MALDI-TOF MS cannot be overemphasized (172). Although databases have improved, some users are supplementing the available commercial databases with their own in-house-developed databases to allow species-level differentiation of NTM and account for regional diversity within a species (169). MALDI-TOF MS methods for mycobacteria have continued to advance, but further development is needed. Routine identification of the M. abscessus subspecies remains challenging. Attempts to develop a method to identify subspecies by using single-peak analysis have been hampered by geographic differences in strains and gene transfer between subspecies. A set of standard peaks that can be used to distinguish the three subspecies has not been defined, leaving sequence analysis of multiple targets as the best method for identification at this time (185, 186).

Future developments suggested for MALDI-TOF MS might include further refinement of the databases; possible typing of organisms; detection of the absence or presence of specific proteins associated with virulence and antimicrobial resistance; and development of methods for direct detection and identification from clinical samples (168).

sect1.title: Pulsed-Field Gel Electrophoresis
sect1.para: Pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) is the most widely used method for molecular strain typing of the RGM. Although PFGE has never been standardized for RGM, most investigators concur that small (2 or 3 bands) differences between isolates indicate that the isolates are closely related, differences of 4 to 6 bands indicate that the strains are possibly related, and differences of ≥7 bands indicate that the isolates are genetically different (27, 187). Because unrelated strains of most RGM contain highly diverse PFGE patterns, this technique has been useful in epidemiological investigations including an extended outbreak of the M. abscessus species in a tertiary care hospital from 2013 to 2015 (106). With the addition of thiourea as a modification of the original method, it is now possible to obtain reliable results by PFGE for all species of RGM, including isolates previously affected by DNA degradation (188, 189). Recent studies have shown that DNA smear patterns of previous isolates are correlated with the presence of the dnd locus, which contains a DNA degradation gene (190).

sect1.title: Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA PCR
sect1.para: In the random amplified polymorphic DNA PCR (RAPD-PCR) method, using one arbitrary primer and low-stringency conditions, the primer hybridizes to both strands of template DNA, where it is matched or partially matched, resulting in strain-specific heterogeneous DNA products. Zhang and colleagues applied the RAPD-PCR or arbitrarily primed PCR analysis method to compare strains ofM. abscessus species (188). They were able to confirm several previous observations about prior health care-related RGM outbreaks, including a 1988 epidemic of otitis media due to aminoglycoside-resistant M. abscessus species in children with prior tympanostomy tubes, as well as a cardiac surgery outbreak (1, 93, 188).

sect1.title: VNTR Analysis
sect1.para: The development of strain typing methods using VNTR would be valuable for helping to explain differences between isolates from chronic new infections and relapse infections. Blauwendraat and colleagues also indicated that the method would show whether cross-infection occurs and, moreover, enable prospective studies of strains of theM. abscessus species correlated with clinical outcomes (157). In 2012, Wong et al. (191) described a VNTR typing assay (MavA) using 18 tandem repeats in the M. abscessus genomic sequence, which was found to be superior to multilocus sequencing, with 100% typeability, 100% locus stability, and 100% reproducibility. More recently, VNTR typing has also been useful to identify outbreak strains of the M. abscessus species in a tertiary care hospital (106).

sect1.title: Repetitive-Sequence-Based PCR
sect1.para: A commercial system (although not yet FDA cleared), DiversiLab (bioMérieux, Durham, NC), is available for strain typing of organisms, including mycobacteria, by using repetitive elements interspersed throughout the genome. The system electrophoretically separates repetitive-sequence-based PCR (rep-PCR) amplicons on microfluidic chips to provide computer-generated readouts. The discriminative power has been reported to equal or exceed that of standard restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis for some species of mycobacteria, with a smaller sample size than that for standard PFGE and in a much shorter time frame (153, 192). Limitations of the system include the lack of an extensive established database and the cost of the system.

sect1.title: Enterobacterial Repetitive Intergenic Consensus PCR (ERIC PCR)
sect1.para: Enterobacterial repetitive consensus sequences are repetitive elements distributed along the bacterial chromosome, at intergenic regions of polycistronic operons or flanking open reading frames. The method was evaluated with isolates of theM. abscessus/M. chelonae species and with isolates of M. fortuitum. Typing of isolates by ERIC PCR works in mycobacteria as a RAPD-PCR because the presence of ERIC repeats has never been demonstrated in available Mycobacterium genomes, and amplification with appropriate ERIC primers can occur in the absence of genuine ERIC sequences. In a study of outbreak strains of M. abscessus in Brazil, ERIC PCR showed higher discriminatory power than PFGE for typing of strains that had shown smear patterns with PFGE without thiourea, although this method was not as discriminatory when testing isolates of M. fortuitum (112).

sect1.title: Whole-Genome Sequencing
sect1.para: WGS has emerged as a specialized method for studying genetic variation and performing population genomics studies on nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), including some species (primarily theM. abscessus species) in the RGM. This method has allowed us to identify genetic factors that characterize the species diversity and specificity of RGM and has provided insight into aspects of survival in the environment, such as resistance to antibiotics, as well as the evolutionary process and general pathogenicity of strains and species (193–198). It has also been instrumental in facilitating our understanding of the epidemiological features and global relatedness of the M. abscessus species. In a series of studies, epidemiological analyses of the M. abscessus species have been conducted at different scales, including outbreaks within a single hospital (78, 199), nationwide (200–202), and even the intercontinental spread of this pathogen (80, 203). Importantly, WGS has provided the first evidence of possible person-to-person transmission of M. abscessus subsp. massiliense (78, 79). However, there are cases that show high genetic relatedness between clinical isolates despite the fact that there is no epidemiological link between patients (199, 204), highlighting that tracking patient-to-patient transmission solely based on WGS analysis of clinical isolates should be approached with caution and that epidemiological support is still needed at present. A gold standard method for analyzing the transmission dynamics of the M. abscessus species based on WGS data has not yet been established, and further studies are needed. Using WGS data for geographically diverse M. abscessus species clinical isolates, Bryant and colleagues revealed that the majority of isolates formed dense clusters with low genetic diversity, with two M. abscessus subsp. abscessus and one M. abscessus subsp. massiliense clones dominating the worldwide distribution (80). Although this study also revealed that clustered strains are more virulent and more likely to acquire drug resistance than nonclustered strains, the genetic factors that cause this and the characteristics of each cluster are not yet clear. At present, most of these epidemiological findings have been obtained from the analysis of clinical isolates derived from patients with cystic fibrosis in Western countries, and there are few examples of analyses from other regions and in non-CF patients. WGS not only provides epidemiological insights but also is an emerging tool for the development of molecular diagnostic assays. Based on the findings from WGS analysis of the M. abscessus species clinical isolates, researchers have recently developed a method of discriminating subspecies and mutations associated with drug resistance: subspecies identification by amplification of genomic regions associated with each of the three subspecies (205, 206). Furthermore, by amplifying genomic region-associated strains that are susceptible to macrolide antibiotics, which are the key drug used to treat M. abscessus species infections, this method is able to differentiate macrolide-susceptible populations among the M. abscessus species clinical isolates with ease and high accuracy (206). Future molecular biological and epidemiological studies and molecular assay development will be based on the findings from WGS. In this context, WGS is undoubtedly an important tool for the genetic characterization of NTMs, including RGM, even though the bioinformatics skills needed to analyze WGS data have not yet been fully embraced by researchers in clinical and reference laboratories, most likely due to cost and lack of availability of bioinformatics experts to interpret findings in a meaningful way.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Serologic classification of mycobacteria has been attempted, starting in 1925 withM. avium complex. However, serotyping has not been suitable for routine species identification of mycobacteria including the RGM, and early studies served to emphasize the complexity of the antigenic composition of mycobacteria, with many antigens shared by more than one species (207).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Several different methods have been used for susceptibility testing of RGM for clinical purposes. These methods include agar disk diffusion, broth microdilution, agar disk elution, and Etest. Each method has proved useful, but none of the methods were well standardized until 2003 with the publication of the CLSI guidelines (208). In the M24A document, the CLSI recommended broth microdilution as the reference method for susceptibility testing of the RGM, and it continues to be recommended in the latest edition (209, 210). Ten antimicrobials, including amikacin, cefoxitin, ciprofloxacin, clarithromycin, doxycycline, linezolid, imipenem, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, tigecycline, and tobramycin, have been recommended for minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) testing, and breakpoints have been established for all but one (tigecycline) of these agents. Breakpoints for two other antimicrobial agents, meropenem and minocycline, are also the same as imipenem and doxycycline, respectively (210). Tigecycline MICs should be reported without interpretation since there are currently no standardized breakpoints for this agent (210).

MICs are optimally read after incubation at 30°C for 3 days. A few RGM species, including some species within theM. fortuitum group, may be readable at 48 hours, but most of the clinically relevant species, including the M. abscessus/chelonae species, do not have adequate growth until 3 to 5 days. The CLSI recommends not reporting MICs (except for clarithromycin) after 5 days due to possible drug degradation (209). Clarithromycin MICs should be read initially at 3 to 5 days and again at up to 14 days in order to phenotypically demonstrate inducible macrolide resistance by the erm gene. The principle of this testing is discussed briefly below and in detail in chapter 79. Several additional newer antimicrobials, including omadacycline, eravacycline, tedizolid, bedaquiline, clofazimine, and β-lactamase inhibitor antimicrobials, are undergoing evaluations. However, these have not yet been addressed by the CLSI. These are discussed in more detail in chapter 79.

Several specific recommendations about test results have also been made. Tobramycin should only be reported for isolates ofM. chelonae. Any RGM isolate with an amikacin MIC of ≥64 μg/ml should be retested and/or sent to a reference laboratory in order to confirm resistance (although mutational resistance involving the 16S rRNA gene does occur). Also, if any isolate of the M. fortuitum group has an imipenem MIC of >8 μg/ml, this test should also be repeated with careful attention paid to inoculum density and a maximum incubation time of 3 days because of the instability of imipenem over time.

Another caveat is that the MICs of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are read using 80% inhibition of growth as the susceptibility endpoint, not 100% inhibition as is used for the other antimicrobials. Overinoculation of the MIC panels is often most obvious with sulfonamides. An inexperienced laboratorian may interpret the sulfonamide MIC as resistant when in reality the inoculum may be too heavy. Rarely, isolates of theM. fortuitum group are resistant to sulfonamides. If an isolate in this group is found resistant, a repeat test with lower inoculum is warranted (209).

The recent finding of the presence of a functionalerm gene that induces macrolide resistance in many isolates of the M. fortuitum group and M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, but not M. chelonae or M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, has also changed the manner in which clarithromycin reporting should be done (132, 133, 211, 212). The significance of the finding of these genes has not yet been assessed in clinical trials. However, a landmark study in Korea among 64 patients with M. abscessus subsp. abscessus and 81 patients with M. abscessus subsp. massiliense lung disease showed that approximately 80% of the patients with M. abscessus subsp. massiliense could be successfully treated with a macrolide-containing multidrug regimen, in contrast to only about 20% of the patients with M. abscessus subsp. abscessus (69). The investigators suggested that inducible resistance to clarithromycin could explain the decreased efficacy of clarithromycin-containing antibiotic regimens against M. abscessus lung disease (69).

Following recentin vitro erm gene studies, it is possible to report isolates (e.g., most strains of M. abscessus subsp. abscessus, M. porcinum, and M. abscessus subsp. bolletii) as macrolide resistant, obviating the need for a 14-day incubation if the isolate has been identified by molecular methods (i.e., gene sequencing) as a species or subspecies with a known functional erm gene. Similarly, species or subspecies with no functional erm gene, including M. senegalense, M. peregrinum, M. chelonae, M. immunogenum, the M. mucogenicum group, and M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, may be reported as clarithromycin susceptible (132, 133, 210–215). See Table 4.
Further details of the antimicrobial susceptibility method and guidance for patient therapy may be found inchapter 79 of this Manual.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Dramatic taxonomic changes, largely attributed to the advent of molecular testing, have occurred over the past 10 to 20 years. Multiple new species have been introduced, and some former subspecies have attained species status. Of the more than 100 validly published species of RGM, approximately one-third have been described within the past 10 years.

The recommended species and subspecies identification methods are evolving, with declining interest and efficiency of phenotypic testing and HPLC and increasing availability and accuracy of molecular methods and MALDI-TOF MS. Phenotypic tests have limited utility and are best applied in conjunction with molecular methods. Currently, molecular and/or proteomic methods are preferred and are generally the only way to identify many newer species or subspecies. Laboratories in which molecular testing is unavailable should consider referring RGM isolates to a reference laboratory with molecular capabilities (131).

The major species of RGM (seeTable 1) each have different drug susceptibility patterns and different virulence in different clinical settings. The diagnostic priorities in terms of disease include bloodstream infection (usually catheter sepsis), disseminated or posttraumatic wound infection, and pulmonary disease (especially in the setting of bronchiectasis). For example, M. mucogenicum is a recognized cause of catheter sepsis, but because of its common presence in tap water the species is usually considered a contaminant in sputum. The most common RGM isolated from pulmonary specimens and associated with disease is the M. abscessus species. However, other RGM such as M. fortuitum, which is rarely considered a pathogen except in the setting of achalasia or lipoid pneumonia, may also be recovered from respiratory samples. The pathogenic potential of the RGM is generally related to clinical findings (unexplained fever, dimorphic inflammatory lesions, etc.), immune status of the patient, number of positive cultures, quantity of organisms in the sample recovery from smear-positive samples, and sources of the recovered species (47). Some established and newly described species have been identified from environmental samples but as yet not identified as human or animal pathogens (122). These factors emphasize the necessity to perform species-level identification and susceptibility testing on clinically significant isolates of RGM. Furthermore, isolates recovered from a single sample are less likely to be significant than those from multiple samples.

When species identification of a clinically significant isolate is not available (i.e., susceptibility may be finalized prior to identification of species), MICs should be reported for antimicrobials as recommended by the CLSI. An identification such as “Rapidly growingMycobacterium sp.” may be acceptable until identification has been performed. However, the report should include a comment that tobramycin is reported only for M. chelonae (209).

As previously commented in this chapter, the nomenclature designation of the collectiveM. abscessus (formerly complex) is currently “the M. abscessus species,” and laboratory reporting should reflect this change, especially in preliminary reporting when the subspecies is unknown.

When MIC results are reported, an interpretation of MIC values (i.e., “susceptible,” “intermediate,” or “resistant”) should be given for each antimicrobial for which there are recommended breakpoints (209). For agents such as tigecycline for which no breakpoints have been recommended, an MIC value with a notation that “no CLSI breakpoints have been established for this species” should accompany the report. Moreover, because of the documented lack of efficacy for the use of first-line tuberculosis drugs (i.e., ethambutol, rifampin, isoniazid), laboratories should not routinely report MICs for these agents against RGM (131). Other antimicrobials including tedizolid, omadacycline, eravacycline, bedaquiline, and clofazimine have also been studied against the RGM, and details are included in chapter 79 of this Manual. Furthermore, for cultures that remain positive for the same species after 6 months of appropriate antimicrobial therapy, confirmation of species identification by molecular methods and repeat antimicrobial susceptibility testing is warranted (209).

Although recent advances in antimicrobial therapies, including the new macrolides, fluoroquinolones, oxazolidinones, tigecycline, and more recently omadacycline and eravacycline (216, 217), have enhanced the therapeutic options and improved the prognosis for RGM disease, there is still a compelling need for the development of more efficient, effective, and safe oral antimicrobials for treatment.

For example, mostM. abscessus subsp. abscessus lung disease is still generally considered incurable with the currently available antimicrobials. Susceptibility testing of the RGM is necessary in order to select optimal antimicrobial therapy and to monitor the development of mutational drug resistance that may occur with the prolonged therapy required for RGM disease.
